review_detail: In the masterful hands of the director and boosted by a deliciously manipulative performance by Kate Beckinsale, this feels like the most refreshing take on Austen's work ever put on screen.
Love & Friendship may not be traditional Austen, but it's pretty stellar Stillman.
A lesser-known novel by Jane Austen becomes an auspicious foray into costume drama by Whit Stillman. Kate Beckinsale shines.
Love & Friendship is one of Mr. Metropolitan's best.

A delicious marriage of Whit Stillman and Jane Austen in a comedy of manners with a contemporary spin that delights from start to twisty finish.

Not among the best of Jane Austen's novels is given a decent adaptation.

The most refreshing take on Austen's work ever put on screen.
One of the funniest comedies of manners since the heyday of Ernst Lubitsch.

Whit Stillman and Jane Austen are a match made in comedy rapture.

Immensely charming and laugh-out-loud funny.

Austen-isms walk shoulder to shoulder with Stillman-isms so gracefully that it takes a moment to realize which author is likely speaking through these characters.

One of the most ingenious movies of recent memory and also the funniest.
Beckinsale is fantastic and probably has the funniest and snarkiest lines in the movie. It's better than Stillman's last few movies.
The sharpest, least sentimental and possibly the best version of Austen yet.

Best ever Kate Beckinsale, could have been naughtier

It's the cinematic version of inventing a chocolate bar that makes you lose weight - something really tasty that's actually good for you.
It's securely in its proper time and place, but this is an unusual side of Austen, cooler and more nakedly cunning. It feels very modern indeed.

What a lovely meeting, a novelist who was ahead of her time and a filmmaker determinedly, irretrievably outside his own. It's like two very different people meeting on a blind date, and suddenly sparks are flying.

An onrushing delight, captured in bright and creamy light... a vessel for Kate Beckinsale's liquid lashings of the tongue, but Lady Susan is of no time, and of this time, and the most modern of characters, as in [Stillman's] earlier near-period pieces.

Love & Friendship is quick, clever and delightful, very funny and hugely entertaining.

Love & Friendship is Jane Austen's world at its most devilishly delightful, with Kate Beckinsale giving the performance of her career as a woman who is a schemer, a fortune-hunter, a silver-tongued devil.

Even though this is a walking and talking film, except in those instances when it's a sitting and talking film, Stillman keeps everything moving fast, fast, fast while the script crackles and spits and bites.
A delightful comic romp that fans of the classic English author will love.
